name: NPR
text:
Dr. Fauci says Americans need to "double down on public health measures" until a vaccine arrives â€” "which will be soon."

"If you're fighting a battle, and the cavalry's on the way, you don't stop shooting. You keep going until the cavalry gets here." https://t.co/Oorhif93RY

name: NPR
text:
Facebook says users saw hate speech about once in every 1,000 pieces of content they viewed on the site between July and September.

It's the first time Facebook has publicly estimated the prevalence of hate speech on its platform.
https://t.co/HfHk44AbQl

name: NPR
text: JUST IN: Georgia election officials have released a report on the hand recount of the presidential election, affirming Joe Biden maintains his lead in the state. https://t.co/PnDEbifLSX

name: NPR
text: RT @LouderThanARiot: Join us tomorrow for a conversation with @craftingmystyle about all things #LouderThanARiot. https://t.co/otaIdHtSjj

name: NPR
text:
There are fewer homes for sale in the U.S. now than ever recorded in nearly 40 years of data. It's a big part of what's pushing home prices up to record highs â€” and making homeownership unaffordable for so many.  
https://t.co/nGtggbmwhl

name: NPR
text:
JUST IN: President-elect Joe Biden has won Georgia, according to the AP's final race call, flipping a state which has been reliably Republican for decades.

The final electoral tally:

Biden: 306 votes 
Trump: 232 votes
https://t.co/lOCGXEjQ2S

name: NPR
text:
New, injectable anti-AIDS drugs only need to be taken a few times a year â€”  rather than a daily pill â€” and may soon be available in many parts of the world.

Patients say they're more convenient and less stigmatizing.
https://t.co/va30jJMHPx

name: NPR
text:
Denmark's agriculture minister has resigned following backlash against the government order to cull all minks in the country.

Last week it emerged that the government didn't have legislation in place for such an order.
https://t.co/PAPcns8Ptf

name: NPR
text:
Calif. Gov. Gavin Newsom has ordered a curfew for the state's 41-high risk counties, requiring most residents to stay in their homes between 10 p.m. to 5 a.m. The order extends until Dec. 21.
https://t.co/7jCe2D4tw6

name: NPR
text:
On Tuesday morning, as New Yorkers brutally criticized the 2020 Rockefeller Center Christmas Tree for being too scrappy, the tree struck back by revealing a tiny trapped owl. 

It shall have its revenge! And/or "all the mice it can eat." @Gothamist https://t.co/dJ3X44Wv96

name: NPR
text:
In his first interview with Terry Gross, Obama talks about what he misses most about being president and reflects on the turmoil of the Trump White House.

He says there's "no doubt" democracy has been strained â€” but he doesn't believe it's broken.
https://t.co/bRCbWlvIKo

name: NPR
text:
Betsy DeVos railed against public education, helped reverse guidance protecting trans students and beefed up protections for college students accused of sexual assault.

Here's a look at the legacy she will leave behind.
https://t.co/IKWlqEKsfV

name: NPR
text:
Tyson Foods Inc. has suspended managers at an Iowa pork plant who were accused of participating in a betting pool on how many employees would become ill with COVID-19.
https://t.co/ZYFkM6JWR2

name: NPR
text:
National security is one of the major reasons smooth transitions are so crucial, experts say.

The 9/11 Commission pointed to the shortened transition period between the Clinton and Bush administrations as playing a role in al-Qaida's attack in 2001.
https://t.co/IdZGNyNrsW

name: NPR
text:
As medical professionals around the country grapple with soaring numbers of COVID-19 sickened people, they're also combatting another quick-spreading and dangerous contagion: misinformation about the virus.
https://t.co/LSZKjWshB8

name: NPR
text:
The delay in the presidential transition threatens to harm everything from the government's response to the coronavirus to matters of national security, says Dave Barram, who led the GSA during the 2000 transition.
 https://t.co/k7ZH2hwsyI

name: NPR
text:
Researchers have found a disturbing pattern: People who live in U.S. neighborhoods once subjected to redlining are more likely to experience shorter life spans today â€” sometimes as much as 20 or 30 years shorter than other places in the same city.
 https://t.co/dBH6MKB57u

name: NPR
text:
Even before the pandemic, depression, anxiety and other mental health issues were on the rise in kids. School shutdowns and social isolation are making conditions worse. 

â€œTheyâ€™re giving up hope. There's nowhere to go. There's nothing to do." @KQEDnews https://t.co/5TkHIvxkeL

name: NPR
text:
Pfizer is on the verge of filing with the FDA for emergency use authorization for its COVID-19 vaccine.
https://t.co/6caHP3yi1y

name: NPR
text:
Top House Democrats are demanding that GSA chief Emily Murphy brief lawmakers on why she has delayed ascertaining President-elect Biden's win. 

The senior lawmakers gave her until Monday to provide the briefing.
https://t.co/QTXDnzwOFK

name: NPR
text: Join the hosts of @louderthanariot today at 3pm ET / 12pm PT for a conversation that goes behind-the-scenes of NPR Music's first narrative podcast series, which dives into the interconnected rise of hop-hop and mass incarceration. https://t.co/Sv4HjOaRNg https://t.co/tfgoyXOQyH

name: NPR
text:
India's total reported coronavirus infections have surpassed 9 million. That's the second-highest in the world, behind the United States.
https://t.co/Ff3kRMkn3t

name: NPR
text:
RT @NPRGoatsandSoda: The mosquito-borne virus Zika swept across Central and South America in 2015 but never exploded in Africa. 

Scientists think it might have to do with the critter that spreads the disease â€“ or more specifically, the subspecies of the critter.   https://t.co/W0U1VPeFcZ

name: NPR
text:
Pfizer has announced that it's formally asking the FDA to authorize its COVID-19 vaccine for emergency use.
https://t.co/KNkoxQpl9I

name: NPR
text:
Opinion: Thanksgiving could become a national superspreader event with catastrophic consequences, a doctor warns. 

Read their plea for Americans to stay home: https://t.co/29urK74xKX

name: NPR
text:
RT @nprpolitics: JUST IN: The Georgia Secretary of Stateâ€™s office has officially certified the results of the 2020 election, which includes President-elect Bidenâ€™s victory. 

The certification comes after the conclusion of a hand recount and audit of approximately 5 million ballots.JUST IN: The Georgia Secretary of Stateâ€™s office has officially certified the results of the 2020 election, which iâ€¦ https://t.co/5nhpO8Fo0r

name: NPR
text:
JUST IN: President-elect Joe Biden has officially been certified the winner of Georgia's 16 electoral votes following a statewide recount. 

Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger said the "numbers don't lie" about Biden's victory. https://t.co/HGNnqaTUMG

name: NPR
text:
The president will meet with two GOP leaders of the Michigan Legislature today. The state plans to certify its election results Monday.

A Biden campaign adviser calls the meeting "an abuse of office" and "an open attempt to intimidate election officials." https://t.co/XcrxG1d085

name: NPR
text: UPDATE: Georgia Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger's office has corrected itself, saying the certification of the state's presidential election results isn't yet complete, but will be finished later today. https://t.co/W8sRjjjpzK

name: NPR
text:
Last July, a self-proclaimed anti-feminist shot and killed Judge Esther Salas's son and wounded her husband in their home.

Now, there's bipartisan support for legislation that would shield the information of federal judges and their families.
https://t.co/I846JeDCyL

name: NPR
text:
RT @WBEZ: The dramatic racial gap in COVID-19 deaths in Chicago has narrowed slightly since the earliest weeks of the pandemic, but the disparities persist, our analysis finds. 

More from @mizamudio: https://t.co/xpgDSHNPDQ

name: NPR
text:
RT @LouderThanARiot: HAPPENING SOON: Join #LouderThanARiot virtual event on YouTube at 3 PM ET. 

https://t.co/a6tyWLxCep https://t.co/J8nI1SG9lZ

name: NPR
text:
El Paso County is posting job openings for morgue workers â€” as the local death toll from COVID-19 rises.

It comes as officials had been relying on low-level inmates from the county jail to assist with moving remains of the deceased.
https://t.co/RY3MuMoju0

name: NPR
text:
Azerbaijani troops have moved into Aghdam â€” the first of three districts around the disputed region of Nagorno-Karabakh to be ceded to the country under its latest cease-fire with Armenia.
https://t.co/NzX1mWeQd2

name: NPR
text:
Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin wants the Federal Reserve to return money allocated for emergency lending programs set up in response to the pandemic.

But the Fed, which manages the programs, is pushing back.
https://t.co/K3CXrLu3dO

name: NPR
text:
A World Health Organization review panel has issued new guidelines recommending against the use of remdesivir for COVID-19.

It says the drug has "no meaningful effect on mortality or on other important outcomes for patients."
https://t.co/FQcthHdGvJ

name: NPR
text:
Donald Trump is already the subject of investigations by New York officials â€” and there's a chance federal authorities may implicate him.

One thing is certain: As a private citizen, he'll no longer enjoy de facto immunity. 
https://t.co/vwcusp1M2h

name: NPR
text: UPDATE: President-elect Joe Biden is now officially certified as the winner of Georgia's 16 electoral votes. https://t.co/kb5nQRZvHN

name: NPR
text:
Scientists now have a better understanding of why the Zika virus exploded in South America but not in Africa, despite originating there.

It likely boils down to the mosquito â€” or more specifically, the subspecies of mosquito â€” that spreads the disease.
